<topcClas>Child development and child rearing - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>General - Employment and labour</topcClas>         <topcClas>Income, property and investment - Economics</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The dataset was derived from childhood waves of the 'National Child Development Study' (NCDS - available from UKDA under GN 33004), during the course of a project funded by the ESRC's <i>Health Variations Programme</i>, titled 'Income Dynamics and Health Inequalities'. One of the major aims of this project was to explore the role of income in generating health  inequalities within a life course perspective. The influence of family income in childhood on later health outcomes,  therefore became one of the central focuses of the study.<br> <br> For the second edition (August 2008), the serial number has been replaced with a new one, variable Ncdsid. This change has been made for all datasets in the NCDS series. Further information may be found in the 'CLS Confidentiality and Data Security Review', included in the documentation.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The dataset contains the following variables:<ul><li>ncdsid - serial number</li><li>p-faminc - predicted log permanent family income (Wave 3)</li><li>data-3 - valid data wave 3 of survey</li><li>data-2 - valid data wave 2 of survey</li><li>data-1 - valid data wave 1 of survey</li><li>data-0 - valid data birth survey</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd>Information was collected by NCDS - 1958 birth cohort - at the birth survey and subsequently when cohort members were aged 7, 11 and 16 years.</timePrd>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <geogUnit>No information recorded</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Children</universe>         <universe>Families</universe>         <universe>Parents</universe>         <universe>Young people</universe>         <universe>Respondents to the NCDS, starting with the Perinatal Mortality Survey in 1958, and the following three waves - 1965, 1969, and 1974 (when respondents were aged 7, 11 and 16 years respectively).</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Data compiled from NCDS.</timeMeth>         <sampProc>Purposive selection/case studies</sampProc>         <sampProc>The sample for permanent income data was limited to those cases where all valid data exists in each of the NCDS childhood waves, and only to those respondents with at least one natural parent at Wave 3 of the survey (see documentation for further details).</sampProc>         <deviat>(A) 8,890 (obtained) Sample with no missing predicted income; (B) 14,372 (obtained) Total NCDS wave 3 sample.</deviat>         <collMode>Compilation or synthesis of existing material</collMode>         <sources>           <dataSrc>Data are derived from childhood waves of the 'National Child Development Survey' (held under GN:33004), obtained from the Data Archive.</dataSrc>         </sources>         <weight>No information recorded.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. See <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx>terms and conditions of access</a> for further information.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
